title: Film: “Los Niños de María” (2018)
desc: Producer Laura Duque scheduled to appear in person for Q&A! This documentary follows the lives of several children in the aftermath of Hurricane María, which hit Puerto Rico on Sept. 20, 2017. It captures the trauma of living through the hurricane, the emotional and material impact on families, and the work of recovery — all from the perspective of children. Part of the Listening to Puerto Rico project, which seeks to raise awareness and to promote solidarity through action. Followed by Q&A with producer Laura Duque. Free but ticketed.
more: Tuesday, March 19; 7:30 p.m. at the Browning Cinema, DeBartolo Performing Arts Center

title: Film: “Rear Window” (1954)
desc: Laid up with a broken leg, professional photographer L.B. “Jeff” Jefferies (James Stewart) combats the cabin fever swelling about his mid-century New York apartment with some binoculars and voyeurism. Looking out his rear window to a shared courtyard, he becomes enthralled with the lives he follows, bringing in his girlfriend Lisa (Grace Kelly) into the peeping. When they suspect a potential murder and the couple decides to crack the case, the once-giant gulf between the apartment and the courtyard quickly collapses as tension builds. Students: free. Faculty/Staff: $6
more: Wednesday, March 27; 7:30 p.m. at the Browning Cinema, DeBartolo Performing Arts Center

title: Recital: Liederabend with Fortepiano
desc: Critically hailed French fortepianist Laure Colladant will join with ND voice faculty and “The Eight” (singers from the graduate voice studio) to present a unique, multi-singer performance of Schumann’s beloved song cycles, Dichterliebe and Liederkreis, Op. 39. Colladant will also play solo repertoire by Brahms on Notre Dame’s exquisite fortepiano. This recital is free, open to the public and not ticketed.
more: Wednesday, March 27; 7:30 p.m. in LaBar Recital Hall, O’Neill Hall of Music

title: Film: “Koyaanisqatsi” (1982)
desc: Philip Glass scheduled to appear in person! Perhaps the most famous poetic documentary ever made, Godfrey Reggio’s debut as a film director and producer was the first in what became the “Qatsi” trilogy. The title is a Hopi Indian word meaning “life out of balance” with its power, mystery and attraction still resonating almost 40 years later. Created between 1975 and 1982, the film is an apocalyptic vision of the collision of two different worlds: urban life and technology versus the environment, with a musical score composed by Philip Glass that expands greatly the viewers’ experiences with the film. Students: $4. Faculty/Staff: $6.
more: Thursday, March 28; 7 p.m. at the Browning Cinema, DeBartolo Performing Arts Center

title: Film: “A Bread Factory, Part One” (2018)
desc: This is the first of the two-part loving story of the fictional-yet-all-very-familiar The Bread Factory, a community arts center in the small town of Checkford, told in two films. After 40 years of running The Bread Factory, Dorothea and Greta are suddenly fighting for survival when a celebrity couple — performance artists from China — come to Checkford and build an enormous complex down the street catapulting big changes in their small town. Students: $4. Faculty/Staff: $6.

desc: The second installment of Wagner’s “Ring Cycle,” “Die Walküre,” stars heroic soprano Christine Goerke as the warrior goddess Brünnhilde, whose encounter with the mortal twins Siegmund and Sieglinde, sung by Stuart Skelton and Eva-Maria Westbroek, leads her on a journey from Valhalla to earthbound humanity. Philippe Jordan conducts. Students: $16. Faculty/Staff: $23.

desc: Dr. Seuss’ allegory on environmentalism and the perils of corporate greed makes the trip from beloved book to beloved film in this animated feature. title: Film: “PlantPure Nation” (2015)
desc: This documentary film tells the story of three people on a quest to spread the message of one of the most important health breakthroughs of all time. After renowned nutritional scientist and best-selling author T. Colin Campbell gives a stirring speech on the floor of the Kentucky House of Representatives, his son, Nelson, and Kentucky State Rep. Tom Riner work together to propose a pilot program documenting the health benefits of a plant-based diet. Free but ticketed.
